topic.title: View static ZeroNet sites via browsers without JavaScript support.
topic.body:
For static ZeroNet sites, I can view them via `w3m` indirectly:

```sh
curl -I -s http://127.0.0.1:43110/1AMh6MG4K59ki1dPXX1PrgzeeqkMmZ1YKm/  >/dev/null
w3m $pathToZeroNet/data/1AMh6MG4K59ki1dPXX1PrgzeeqkMmZ1YKm/index.html
```

Replace `w3m` with other browser, such an lynx and elinks, or firefox with NoScript enabled.

7_13Z7XxTa7JuFat3KzzMWu3onwM6biLuurJ.body:
So there is three problems:

1. migration

    As @nofish pointed out, the proposed new architecture hurts performance.
    And changing architecture is much more difficult than writing a migration script for the current architecture.

2. censorship

    The ultimate solution is hosting your own hub.
    For a multiple users hub, the question is: 1) Do you trust the hub owner? 2) Does this hub has an open policy/procedure on censorship.
    
3. scalability

    I think this is the main problem.
    See my next post.

More on scalability:

* Single user hub: Lots of connections.

* Multiple user hub: Small quota. By default, a hub has the normal zite limit (10M), thus every user has a low quota. For example, if a hub hosts 100 users, then every user has less than 100K quota on average. Now let's do some math: suppose on average a user has 600 posts (including comments), and every post is 150 characters (including time stamps), then on average a user will use 150*4*600/1024 = 351k. 351k is already exceeding the  quota. And the above calculation is optimistic. ZeroMe does not limit post length as tweet, thus users tend to write longer posts than twitter.

> my own hub with a 10mb cap per user. And since it's my hub, I can manually adjust that when needed.

If there is an early user on kaffie's hub posts 9.99m, then the quota of all other users joined later will be effectively several kilobytes (unless  every viewer go to kaffie's hub and increase size limit, possible several times).
So multiple users hub still suffers from the quota problem even if site own set a big limit,
just like  those "unlimited storage and bandwidth" hosting plans still suffers from scalability.

>  20% are active, they need to migrate to other hub.

They need to migrate to their own hub.
[A study in 2009](https://sysomos.com/inside-twitter/) shows that 5% of twitter users contributed 75%  of all tweets, 10% for 86%, and the top 20% for 94.32%.
And 15% posted at least a tweet a day.
So no multiple user hub can host these top zeromers within the 10MB size limit.

> 50KB is soon to use up for some of us, so we really need a easy-to-use migrating script( migrating both posts and others' comments ), in the long term, one-click migrating like one-click clone is preferred.

Another approach is to allow a user to post to multiple hubs.
And hubs will be archived when it get close to the size limit,
not accepting new users & posts & comments & liking.
Users may also just seed normal hubs,
if their disk space and/or bandwidth is limited.

3_1JoKQwXPzK8uyvMCRcwvMSAJPD5S4aH5Vt.body:
They are quite similar.

Difference:

- Beaker does not host visited sites.  (You can enable it manually.)
- Beaker sites support versioning. 
- Beaker API is much simpler than ZeroNet, no select user (id), no optional file, no encryption, etc. ZeroNet sites can be more dynamic.
- ZeroNet uses namecoin `.bit`. Beaker uses regular domain names (via TXT record).

Also, because Beaker requires to use a customized browser:
(These are not real differences since anyone can make a customized browser for Zeronet)

- it uses `dat://` schema.
- Beaker sites need to ask user permission to access clearnet.

Other differences are technical details, like ZeroNet is written in Python, Beaker is written in JavaScript. ZeroNet uses base85 encoded site address (compatible with bitcoin), Beaker uses hex encoded address.

> [jsilence](#comment_18_1JoKQwXPzK8uyvMCRcwvMSAJPD5S4aH5Vt): @weakish, thanks for clarifying!
> Wondering how different the dat:// Protocol is from the ZeroNet protocol. Is there any chance for the two to be merged?

As I wrote, they are incompatible.
If the two protocols merged into one protocol, then it would be a new protocol.
And all nodes need to update to join the merged network (that would be a new network).

3_12shzNwEsUKcdzbWYFNH54LJjKzQ7MUwhp.body:
> I don't want people to be able to change the messages the wrote. 
> Currently, there is no native way to fix this in ZeroNet.
> The solution? A BlockChain!

A blockchain is not required.
ZeroNet may add a permission rule for an append only mode.
Then every node see the `"appendOnly": ture` in site's `content.json`,
it will compare new `data.json` of a user with the local version.
If the new version is not append only,
it will refuse to accept the new version.
To prevent a new node visiting the site for the first time to receive invalid `data.json`,
all new nodes need to verify the `data.json` with other nodes
(if there is one node providing `data.json`, the new node accept the `data.json` temporarily,
to verify it later.)

This is not as secure as blockchain but works under most conditions. 

This approach can also be modified to permit a short window for editing posted content.
That is, if a node receive a new `content.json` with record `x` appened,
within n minutes, if it receives a new `content.json` with only record `x` modified,
it will accept it.
After n minutes, it will refuse any modification of record `x`.

1_1AuEW5hXeYuez72w5Kk6hfNbotZozMcvcW.body:
> [zaomeng666](#comment_3_1AuEW5hXeYuez72w5Kk6hfNbotZozMcvcW): 文件是下载了，但貌似没安装到电脑上，不知怎么安装

这是绿色软件，不用安装。

下载解压，到安装目录，启动命令行，输入`ipfs init`初始化配置。
然后使用`ipfs daemon`启动服务。
接着打开 http://127.0.0.1:5001/webui 看下服务是否启动成功。

然后是基本的文件操作。`ipfs add 文件名` 发布文件，`ipfs get 哈希地址`下载文件。
注意老文件会被自动删除。如果希望永久保留文件就`ifps pin add 哈希地址`.
反之`ipfs pin rm 哈希地址`表示不需要解除永久保留状态。`ipfs pin ls`可以列出所有永久保留的文件。
